|accessdate=8 July 2011}} Bersih accused the government of reneging on a previous offer to let them rally in a stadium instead of the streets.{{cite news |title=Government cannot stop us, says Bersih |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/government-cannot-stop-us-says-bersih/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=8 July 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=8 July 2011}} Bersih insisted on gathering at Merdeka Stadium, despite [[#Lockdown|preventative measures]] taken by police. ====Abroad==== Simultaneous rallies in support of Bersih were planned by Malaysian citizens in more than 30 cities in New Zealand, Australia, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Thailand, Indonesia, Egypt, Switzerland, Sweden, Austria, France, [[UK|Great Britain]], Ireland, Canada, the United States and Cambodia.{{cite news |title=Bersih to go global with July 9 rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-to-go-global-with-july-9-rally |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=24 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=30 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Asian democracy crusades take root |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/asian-democracy-crusades-take-root/story-e6frg6ux-1226087447434 |work=The Australian |date=5 July 2011 |last=Hoffstaedter |first=Gerhard |accessdate=8 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Bersih rally goes global |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/07/bersih-rally-goes-global/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |last=Teoh |first=El Sen |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ==Lead-up to the rally== ===Announcement=== After frustration at by being shut out of [[Election monitoring|observing]] the [[Sarawak state election, 2011|April 2011 Sarawak election]], Bersih announced in a press release on 26 May that it had decided to organise a gathering on 9 July to press for electoral reform.{{cite web |title=Bersih 2.0: Deportation of activist from Sarawak and announcement of ‘Perhimpunan Rakyat’ |url=http://bersih.org/?p=3844 |publisher=Bersih |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}} ===Counter-rallies=== ====Perkasa==== [[Ketuanan Melayu|Malay Supremacy]] movement [[Perkasa]] spoke out strongly against the rally.{{cite news |title=Perkasa vows counter-protest against Bersih rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/perkasa-vows-counter-protest-against-bersih-rally/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=13 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=13 June 2011}} On 15 June, Perkasa announced that it had secured the support of over 30 non-governmental organisations and challenged Bersih organisers over who could stage a bigger rally on 9 July.{{cite news |title=Let’s see who’s bigger, Perkasa dares Bersih |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/lets-see-whos-bigger-perkasa-dares-bersih/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=15 June 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=15 June 2011}} It called on Bersih to cancel its rally, warning that clashes might occur. Perkasa president [[Ibrahim Ali (Malaysia)|Ibrahim Ali]] warned "[If they proceed] there will be a clash. If that happens, it is for the better."{{cite news |title=Perkasa ready to counter Bersih rally |url=http://www.freemalaysiakini.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=14002&mode=thread&order=0&thold=0 |work=Free Malaysiakini |date=13 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}} On 19 June, Perkasa held a gathering to protest the Bersih rally and to launch an opposing coalition of NGOs known as Gerak Aman.{{cite news |title=Gerak Aman and Bersih 2.0 launch movements on same day |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/20/nation/8934868&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=20 June 2011 |accessdate=26 June 2011}} During the gathering, images of Ambiga—described by flyers as "a dangerous Hindu woman"—were burned, while Ibrahim warned the Chinese community not to participate in the Bersih rally.{{cite news |title=Ibrahim raises spectre of May 13 at anti-Bersih rally launch |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ibrahim-raises-spectre-of-may 13-at-anti-bersih-rally-launch/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=19 June 2011 |last=Yow |first=Hong Chieh |accessdate=19 June 2011}} On 8 July, Perkasa announced the cancellation of its counter-rally due to its inability to secure a venue and a police permit.{{cite news |title=Perkasa rally in limbo, chief to stay home |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/08/perkasa-rally-in-limbo-chief-to-stay-home/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=8 July 2011 |author=Tarani Palani |accessdate=8 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Perkasa cancels rally, but members to loiter in city |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169283 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=8 July 2011 |last=Kuek Ser |first=Kuang Keng |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ====UMNO Youth==== [[UMNO]] Youth leader [[Khairy Jamaluddin]] announced that UMNO Youth will hold another rally on the same day (known as the "Patriot Rally" or ''Himpunan Patriot''){{cite news |title=Umno Youth's 'Patriot' Counter-rally Launched |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |date=26 June 2011 |accessdate=26 June 2011 |url=http://www.bernama.com/bernama/v5/newsindex.php?id=596886}} to "strengthen the democratic system" and show that "the voice of the people does not belong only to the opposition."{{cite news |title=Umno Youth to gather on July 9, rival Bersih rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/umno-youth-to-gather-on-july-9-rival-bersih-rally/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=16 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Umno Youth to march on July 9 for preserving country's democratic system |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/16/nation/20110616192325&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=16 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}} He added that they had "a right to assembly guaranteed by the constitution."{{cite news |title=Thumbing nose at Hisham, Khairy says march goes on |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/thumbing-nose-at-hisham-khairy-says-march-goes-on/ |date=17 June 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=17 June 2011}} Khairy and Ibrahim became involved in a war of words over the latter's comments on regarding the Chinese community, with each side calling for the other to be investigated under the [[Sedition Act (Malaysia)|Sedition Act]].{{cite news |title=Ibrahim Ali’s remarks not representative of Malays, says Khairy |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ibrahim-alis-remarks-not-representative-of-malays-says-khairy/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=20 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=21 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110621214257/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ibrahim-alis-remarks-not-representative-of-malays-says-khairy/ |archive-date=21 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |title=Perkasa boss slams ‘old cow’ Kit, ‘rich’ Khairy |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/21/perkasa-boss-slams-old-cow-kit-rich-khairy/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=21 June 2011 |author=K Pragalath |accessdate=21 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Perkasa: KJ juga perlu disiasat bawah ISA |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/21/perkasa-kj-juga-perlu-disiasat-bawah-isa/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=21 June 2011 |author=Fazy Sahir |accessdate=21 June 2011}} Ibrahim later backtracked from his comments.{{cite news |title=Ibrahim Ali: I was misunderstood |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ibrahim-ali-i-was-misunderstood/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=21 June 2011 |last=Chooi |first=Clara |accessdate=21 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622231105/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ibrahim-ali-i-was-misunderstood/ |archive-date=22 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} UMNO Youth's plan was to gather at [[Bukit Bintang]] and possibly march towards Merdeka Stadium.{{cite news |title=Umno Youth to defy ban, may rally at Stadium Merdeka |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/08/umno-youth-to-defy-ban-may-rally-at-stadium-merdeka/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=8 July 2011 |author=Syed Jamal Zahiid |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ===Election Commission reaction=== Bersih's demands were repeatedly dismissed by the [[Election Commission of Malaysia|Election Commission]] (EC), who sought to tie the organisation to the opposition's agenda.{{cite news |title=EC: Bersih intends to overthrow govt |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/30/ec-bersih-intends-to-overthrow-govt/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=30 June 2011 |last=Sta Maria |first=Stephanie |accessdate=30 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701100814/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/30/ec-bersih-intends-to-overthrow-govt/ |archive-date=1 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} EC deputy chairman Wan Ahmad Wan Omar claimed Bersih was working with [[Pakatan Rakyat]] to "overthrow the government." In turn, Ambiga criticised the EC's conduct, asking them to remain independent from politics.{{cite news |title=Ambiga tells EC to remain neutral |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ambiga-tells-ec-to-remain-neutral/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=30 June 2011 |last=Yow |first=Hong Chieh |accessdate=30 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701182220/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ambiga-tells-ec-to-remain-neutral/ |archive-date=1 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} On 20 June, the EC extended an offer to Bersih to meet and discuss its demands, on the condition that the rally be called off. He claimed that during a previous meeting with Bersih in 2010, it had agreed that its demands were met.{{cite news |title=EC offers to meet Bersih if rally called off |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ec-offers-to-meet-bersih-if-rally-called-off/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=20 June 2011 |accessdate=20 June 2011}} Bersih rejected the EC's offer.{{cite news |title=Bersih 2.0 to EC: Enough talk, now we walk |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/167494 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=20 June 2011 |author=Hafiz Yatim |accessdate=20 June 2011}} Speaking to reporters while observing the [[Thai general election, 2011|Thai general election]] in July, Abdul Aziz said the EC was considering allowing international observers to monitor the [[next Malaysian general election]].{{cite news |title=EC Mulls Inviting International Observers |url=http://www.bernama.com.my/bernama/v5/newsgeneral.php?id=598215 |publisher=[[Bernama]] |author=Jamaluddin Muhammad |date=1 July 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}} ===Government reaction=== Prime minister [[Najib Razak]] warned that Bersih would be responsible if chaos ensued from the rally.{{cite news |title=PM: July 9 rally organisers would be held responsible if chaos erupts |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/26/nation/20110626132648&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=26 June 2011 |author=Mazwin Nik Anis |accessdate=26 June 2011}} Home Minister [[Hishamuddin Hussein]] warned against the rally, fearing the chaos that might ensue. He affirmed on 7 June that the rally was "illegal," and urged the organisers to call it off.{{cite news |title=‘Ban on illegal demo is for safety’ |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/7/nation/8849506&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'']] |date=7 June 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}} He promised to clamp down on demonstrators if they threatened national security.{{cite news |title=Bersih should clean up its act, says Home Minister |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/5/23/nation/8737547&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'']] |date=23 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=July 9 rally: No easy walk for Bersih, Perkasa |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/15/july-9-rally-no-easy-walk-for-bersih-perkasa/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=15 July 2011 |last=Lee |first=Patrick |accessdate=15 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Thumbing nose at Hisham, Khairy says march goes on |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/thumbing-nose-at-hisham-khairy-says-march-goes-on/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=17 June 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=21 June 2011}} On 22 June, he confirmed that none of the three rallies would receive police permits to hold gatherings on 9 July.{{cite news |title=Hishammuddin: No permits for Bersih, Umno Youth and Perkasa |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/22/nation/20110622125323&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=22 June 2011 |author=Mazwin Nik Anis |accessdate=22 June 2011}} The government also outlawed the wearing and distribution of Bersih's yellow shirts and declared Bersih an illegal organisation under Section 5 of the Societies Act 1966.{{cite news |title=Bersih T-shirts illegal, declares Hisham |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-t-shirts-illegal-declares-hisham/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=29 June 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=29 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Bersih declared unlawful organisation |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/02/bersih-declared-unlawful-organisation/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=2 July 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=3 July 2011}} Bersih countered that as a coalition of groups it need not be registered.{{cite news |title=Bersih 2.0: Coalitions need not be registered |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/168839 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=4 July 2011 |last=Sipalan |first=Joseph |accessdate=4 July 2011}} Najib initially offered Bersih the opportunity of holding the rally in a stadium instead of the streets.{{cite news |title=Pakatan willing to accept Najib’s stadium offer |url=http://my.news.yahoo.com/pakatan-willing-to-accept-najib-s-stadium-offer-043850816.html |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=5 July 2011 |last=Chooi |first=Clara |accessdate=9 July 2011}} The government later rejected Bersih's request to hold the rally at [[Merdeka Stadium]], and asked them to use a stadium in [[Selangor]] instead.{{cite news |title=Malaysia to Block Roads in Bid to Stop Protesters Demanding Fair Elections |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-07-08/malaysia-to-block-roads-in-bid-to-stop-protesters-demanding-fair-elections.html |publisher=Bloomberg |date=8 July 2011 |author1=Manirajan Ramasamy |last2=Gan |first=Yen Kuan |accessdate=8 July 2011}} However, the [[Sharafuddin of Selangor|Sultan of Selangor]] had previously condemned demonstrations.{{cite news |title=Despite obstacles, Bersih remains unwavering |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169357 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ===Opposition reaction=== PAS deputy president [[Mohamad Sabu]] gave the rally his party's full backing.{{cite news |title=Bersih 2.0 diteruskan walau Perkasa halang |url=http://bm.harakahdaily.net/index.php/headline/3766-bersih-20-diteruskan-walau-perkasa-halang |work=Harakah Daily |date=13 June 2011 |author=Nazri Abdullah |accessdate=13 June 2011 }} Calling the event the "Walk for Democracy," he asked for 300,000 PAS members to attend the gathering. PAS president [[Abdul Hadi Awang]] ordered all of its members (numbering one million) to join the rally.{{cite news |title=PAS on million-man march for Bersih |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/pas-on-million-man-march-for-bersih/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=23 June 2011 |last=Yow |first=Hong Chieh |accessdate=23 June 2011}} The Leader of the Opposition, [[Anwar Ibrahim]], will also take part in the rally.{{cite news |title=Anwar ups the ante on Bersih 2.0 |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/166694 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=12 June 2011 |last=Netto |first=Terence |accessdate=13 June 2011}} The DAP also pledged support for the rally. On 19 June, Anwar reportedly told members of his [[Parti Keadilan Rakyat]] (PKR) that he would ask Ambiga to cancel the rally if the government met Bersih's demands.{{cite news |title=Anwar clarifies Bersih rally remark |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/20/anwar-clarifies-bersih-rally-remark/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=20 June 2011 |author=Tarani Palani |accessdate=20 June 2011}} His statement was rebuffed by Ambiga the following day.{{cite news |title=Bersih rally go-ahead not up to Anwar, says Ambiga |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-rally-go-ahead-not-up-to-anwar-says-ambiga/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=20 June 2011 |last=Yow |first=Hong Chieh |accessdate=20 June 2011}} Anwar later claimed he was misquoted. This incident was criticised by ruling coalition parties, who have argued that the rally is in fact an opposition tool to gain support.{{cite news |title=Gerakan in a dilemma over Bersih rally |url=http://www.freemalaysiakini.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=14457&mode=thread&order=0&thold=0 |work=Malaysiakini |date=20 June 2011 |accessdate=20 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Bersih rally tainted, claims Khairy |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-rally-tainted-claims-khairy/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=20 June 2011 |author=Asrul Hadi Abdullah Sani |accessdate=20 June 2011}} ===Non-governmental organisations=== The Bersih rally was backed by the [[Human Rights Commission of Malaysia]] (Suhakam),{{cite news |title=Suhakam: Allow peaceful assembly |url=http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=78367 |work=Daily Express |location=UK |date=28 June 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}} Transparency International Malaysia (TI-M),{{cite news |title=Boost for Bersih from TI-M |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/22/boost-for-bersih-from-ti-m/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=22 June 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}} and the Malaysian Consultative Council of Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, Sikhism and Taoism (MCCBCHST).{{cite news |title=Religious council throws its weight behind all three rallies |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/01/religious-council-throws-its-weight-behind-all-three-rallies/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=1 July 2011 |author=Tarani Palani |accessdate=1 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110703100618/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/01/religious-council-throws-its-weight-behind-all-three-rallies/ |archivedate=3 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The MCCBCHST also backed Perkasa and UMNO Youth's right to hold their rallies. [[Amnesty International]] called on the government to end the "mass repression" of Bersih activists.{{cite web |title=Malaysia: End mass repression of pro-reform activists |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/malaysia-end-mass-repression-pro-reform-activists-2011-06-30 |publisher=[[Amnesty International]] |date=30 June 2011 |accessdate=30 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Int'l NGO calls for end to repression in KL |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/07/01/intl-ngo-calls-end-repression-kl.html |work=The Jakarta Post |date=1 July 2011 |author=Damar Harsanto |accessdate=1 July 2011}} [[Human Rights Watch]] urged the government to release all detained activists, return confiscated material, and permit the rally to proceed.{{cite news |title=Malaysia: End Crackdown on Peaceful Campaigners |url=http://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/malaysia-end-crackdown-on-peaceful-campaigners |author=Human Rights Watch |authorlink=Human Rights Watch |work=AlertNet |date=29 June 2011 |accessdate=29 June 2011}} Deputy Asia director Phil Robertson said "Governments that elected Malaysia to a second term on the [[UN Human Rights Council]] might feel duped." The Asia-Europe Peoples' Forum (AEPF), consisting of 120 international NGOs, condemned the Malaysian government for the crackdown on activists.{{cite news |title=NGOs in Asia and Europe condemn Najib |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/09/ngos-in-asia-and-europe-condemn-najib/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=9 July 2011 |author=Syed Jaymal Zahiid |accessdate=9 July 2011}} ===International response=== On 5 July, the [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]] voiced concern about the restriction of freedom of expression in Malaysia and urged the government to release detained Bersih activists.{{cite web |title=Malaysia: UN rights office concerned at reported crackdown ahead of planned protests |url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=38935&Cr=expression&Cr1 |publisher=UN |date=5 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ===Threats of violence=== On 23 June, Ambiga received a death threat via text message.{{cite news |title=Ambiga receives SMS death threat |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ambiga-receives-sms-death-threat/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=23 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=22 June 2011}} She remained defiant, saying "nothing has changed" and the rally will go on.{{cite news |title=Despite death threat, Ambiga says Bersih rally still on |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/despite-death-threat-ambiga-says-bersih-rally-still-on/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=23 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=23 June 2011}} The grandmaster of the Malaysian [[Silat|Silat Lincah]] Organisation (PSSLM) reportedly threatened to "wage war" against Bersih activists.{{cite news |title=Silat guru to hold 'war' talks tomorrow |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/01/silat-guru-to-hold-war-talks-tomorrow/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=1 July 2011 |author=Syed Jaymal Zahiid |accessdate=1 July 2011}} Najib subsequently endorsed silat groups, including PSSLM.{{cite news |title=Malaysia braces for pro-democracy street protests in Kuala Lumpur |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jul/08/malaysia-democracy-street-protests |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=8 July 2011 |last=Hodal |first=Kate |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ===Yang di-Pertuan Agong's intervention=== Malaysia's head of state, the [[Yang di-Pertuan Agong]], [[Tuanku Mizan Zainal Abidin]], issued a statement on 3 July urging moderation by all parties. He said "street demonstrations bring more bad than good although the original intention is good," and called for Bersih to resolve its differences with the government peacefully. He also expressed confidence in Prime Minister [[Najib Razak]]'s administration.{{cite news |title=King issues statement on Bersih 2.0 rally |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/3/nation/20110703233907&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=3 July 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=3 July 2011}} Following an audience with the King, Ambiga announced that Bersih accepted the government's offer to hold the rally in a stadium instead of the streets.{{cite news |title=Bersih’s Ambiga: No street march, rally will be held in stadium |url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/5/nation/20110705160353&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=5 July 2011 |last=Lee |first=Yen Mun |accessdate=5 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708051317/http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F7%2F5%2Fnation%2F20110705160353&sec=nation |archivedate=8 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |title=Ambiga: Bersih to rally in stadium, not on streets |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ambiga-bersih-to-rally-in-stadium-not-on-streets/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=5 July 2011 |author=Syed Mu’az Syed Putra |accessdate=5 July 2011}} Despite Bersih's meeting with the King, the government maintained its stance that Bersih is illegal.{{cite news |title=Meeting king doesn’t make rally legal |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/06/bersih-still-illegal-says-hisham/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=6 July 2011 |author=Tashny Sukumaran |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ===Police reports and reaction=== At least 2,136 police reports, from business operators, travel agencies, and UMNO Youth, were filed against Bersih since the rally's announcement.{{cite news |title=Deputy IGP: No permit to be issued for Bersih rally |url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/15/nation/20110615135831&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=15 June 2011 |last1=Carvalho |first1=Martin |author2=Rahimy Rahim |last3=Camoens |first3=Austin |accessdate=15 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Eight police reports against Bersih 2.0 rally |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/09/eight-police-reports-against-bersih-2-0-rally/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=9 June 2011 |author=K. Pragalath |accessdate=13 June 2011}} On 15 June, the [[Royal Malaysia Police|police]] announced that permits would not be issued for any rally, saying that the rallies would "disturb the peace" and "cause traffic chaos." Bersih remained defiant despite not receiving the permit, and promised to co-operate with police during the gathering.{{cite news |title=Bersih insists on working with police for rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-insists-on-working-with-police-for-rally/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=15 June 2011 |last=Chi |first=Melissa |accessdate=15 June 2011}} Police also investigated allegations that Ambiga received funds from foreign NGOs "to cause chaos in Malaysia."{{cite news |title=Police to investigate Ambiga’s foreign funds |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/04/police-to-investigate-ambigas-foreign-funds/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=4 July 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=4 July 2011}} Police recorded statements from Ambiga, Ibrahim, and opposition politicians ahead of the rally.{{cite news |title=Cops question Ibrahim, Ambiga and Samad about July 9 rallies |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/28/nation/8987090&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=28 June 2011 |accessdate=28 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Cops quiz MPs in Parliament over Bersih |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/cops-quiz-mps-in-parliament-over-bersih/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=28 June 2011 |last=Chooi |first=Clara |accessdate=28 June 2011}} On 1 July, the police ceased discussions with Bersih, Perkasa and UMNO Youth and promised to prevent any street rallies from taking place.{{cite news |title=Deputy IGP: No more discussions over rallies |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/01/deputy-igp-no-more-discussions-over-rallies/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=1 July 2011 |last=Teoh |first=El Sen |accessdate=1 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Police to make sure July 9 rallies do 'not take place' |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/police-to-make-sure-july-9-rallies-do-not-take-place/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=1 July 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=1 July 2011}} ====Pre-rally arrests and raids==== [[File:Bersih 2 road block.JPG|thumb|The police enforced road blocks throughout the city to discourage turnout.]] More than 150 people were arrested before 9 July for Bersih-related activities, including distributing leaflets.{{cite news |title=Malaysia detains about 60 activists ahead of rally |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5g0tBeEbiYyX0RE7AZE6ItSdD4goQ?docId=0af052a1eba94885850ba537d546b9a4 |agency=Associated Press |authorlink=Associated Press |date=26 June 2011 |accessdate=26 June 2011}} Most were released after several hours of questioning. 30 members of [[Parti Sosialis Malaysia]] (PSM) were arrested in [[Penang]] on 26 June on suspicion of spreading communism and conspiring to overthrow the government.{{cite news |title=30 PSM members remanded till July 2 |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/26/31-psm-members-still-in-police-custody/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=26 June 2011 |first=Humayun |last=Kabir |accessdate=30 June 2011}} Six members, including MP [[Michael Jeyakumar Devaraj]], remain held under the Emergency Ordinance 1969, which allows indefinite detention without trial.{{cite news |title=Malaysia holds MP and five activists under security law |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5j-SBxNFK6HjiZ8l_2__54fOjsSEQ?docId=CNG.29ec5e12b6f0d10f7f43650910da4c43.531 |author=AFP |authorlink=Agence France Presse |date=2 July 2011 |accessdate=3 July 2011}} Police also raided and vandalised Bersih's office in [[Petaling Jaya]] on 30 June.{{cite news |title=Cops raid Bersih office |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/30/nation/9003228&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=30 June 2011 |accessdate=30 June 2011}} One day before the planned rally, police released a list of 91 individuals, including Ambiga, Khairy and Ibrahim, barred from entering Kuala Lumpur's central business district on 9 July.{{cite news |title=91 barred from city tomorrow |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/8/nation/9057686&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ====Lockdown==== Police began imposing roadblocks in the [[Klang Valley]] on Wednesday, 6 July, which led to massive traffic congestion and complaints from the public.{{cite news |title=Thousands left fuming over roadblocks |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/06/thousands-of-motorists-left-fuming-over-police-roadblocks/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=6 July 2011 |last=Teoh |first=El Sen |accessdate=8 July 2011}} They described it as a "preventive" move to stop protesters from participating in the protest.{{cite news |title=Selangor CPO explains Wednesday morning roadblocks |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/6/nation/20110706122426&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=6 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} On 8 July, police sealed off [[Merdeka Square, Kuala Lumpur|Merdeka Square]] and rolled in water cannon and riot police trucks.{{cite news |title=Police deployed at Dataran Merdeka, area sealed off |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169355 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=8 July 2011 |last=Aw |first=Nigel |accessdate=8 July 2011}} At midnight on 9 July, major roads in the city was shut and public transportation suspended.{{cite news |title=Malaysia rally: Kuala Lumpur 'to be locked down' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-14076424 |work=BBC News |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} ==Protests== [[Kuala Lumpur]] was described as a "ghost town" on the morning of 9 July. Many offices and shops were closed as police maintained heavy presences in key areas.{{cite news |title=KL holds its breath as Bersih rally looms |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/kl-holds-its-breath-as-bersih-rally-looms/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} Crowds began pouring in by noon, where they were met by police who took "extraordinary" security measures, known as "Operation Erase Bersih."{{cite news |title=Malaysian police crack down on protesters |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2011/07/20117973119168783.html |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} Many were arrested and transported to the police training center (Pulapol).{{cite news |title=236 held as KL lock-down goes into full swing |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/09/230-held-as-kl-lock-down-goes-into-full-swing/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Malaysia arrests 236 ahead of banned rally |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5haJTubxJ-R5cBUrT3m8K-tD8bLvw?docId=2dcbea0180604e2c82969fb733eb23b5 |agency=Associated Press |date=9 July 2011 |last=Yoong |first=Sean |accessdate=9 July 2011}} The protestors were arrested under Section 27 of the Police Act for planning to participate in illegal rallies, and face several years in prison if convicted. [[File:Bersih 2 protest.jpg|thumb|Protesters marching the streets of Kuala Lumpur peacefully before the police confronted them.]] [[File:Bersih FRU police.jpg|thumb|A member of the Federal Reserve Unit prepares to disperse the protesters with tear gas.]] [[File:Bersih 2 police charging.jpg|thumb|The police force charging at a crowd of regrouping protesters.]] Independent assessments put the rally numbers at between 10,000 and over 20,000, while Bersih claimed a turnout of 50,000.{{cite news|last=Roughneen|first=Simon|title=Malaysia nips an hibiscus uprising|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Southeast_Asia/MG12Ae01.html|accessdate=12 July 2011|newspaper=Asia Times|date=12 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Malaysia police detain hundreds at rally |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jul/09/malaysia-opposition-protests-elections |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=9 July 2011 |agency=Associated Press |authorlink=Associated Press |accessdate=9 July 2011}}{{cite news|last=Barta|first=Patrick|title=Malaysia Protest Lifts Opposition|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304584404576437604262329600|accessdate=11 July 2011|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|date=11 July 2011}} Major gathering points included Menara Maybank, Jalan Pudu, and [[Puduraya]] where riot police confronted protestors.{{cite news |title=Mayhem at Maybank HQ |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/tear-gas-fired-at-bersih-marchers-pas-vps-arrested/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Fortress KL: How did Bersih 2.0 slip past? |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169444 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=10 July 2011 |author=Aidila Razak |accessdate=10 July 2011}} Thousands tried to reach Merdeka Stadium from various parts of the city, chanting ''"Hidup rakyat!"'' ("Long live the people!"). Police responded by firing numerous rounds of [[tear gas]] and chemical-laced water, causing the crowds to disperse into nearby buildings. Police continued to fire tear gas and chemical-laced water at the buildings. Many buildings were targeted by the police including a hospital which the police denied happened even though there are pictures of the water cannons spraying the hospital. At 14:00, Bersih and Pakatan Rakyat leaders began their march towards Merdeka Stadium. Shielded by hundreds of supporters, they pushed past three lines of police personnel awaiting them outside KL Sentral. Around 14:30, while walking with supporters in [[Brickfields]], Ambiga and fellow steering committee member Maria Chin Abdullah were arrested.{{cite news |title=Cops seize Ambiga, Pakatan leaders mid-march |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-leaders-begin-march/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} Opposition politicians detained include [[Abdul Hadi Awang]], [[Mohamad Sabu]], [[Salahuddin Ayub]], [[Mahfuz Omar]], [[Dzulkefly Ahmad]], [[Azmin Ali]], [[Tian Chua]], [[Fuziah Salleh]], [[Sivarasa Rasiah]], and [[Ngeh Koo Ham]].{{cite news |title=Ambiga, Pakatan leaders arrested; Anwar hurt |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/09/ambiga-pakatan-leaders-arrested/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} [[Anwar Ibrahim]] said he sustained a bruise on his head and a cut leg when police fired live rounds.{{cite news |title=Thousands of Malaysians Rally for Changes to Elections |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/10/world/asia/10malaysia.html?_r=1 |work=The New York Times |date=9 July 2011 |last=Gooch |first=Liz |accessdate=10 July 2011}} PAS MP [[Khalid Samad]] was said to have suffered a serious head injury and was admitted to hospital. UMNO Youth's rally in Bukit Bintang however, was allowed to on peacefully without intervention from the police. Around 1,000 protestors eventually reached Merdeka Stadium, including national laureate [[A. Samad Said]] and PAS's [[Husam Musa]].{{cite news |title=Crowd dispersing from Stadium Merdeka, gathering in KLCC |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/headless-bersih-rally-still-growing-at-stadium/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} At around 16:00, the crowd voluntarily began dispersing. However, police continued to fire tear gas and chemical-laced water at any individual and moved in to arrest them. Another group of protestors tried to reach the [[Istana Negara, Jalan Istana|National Palace]], while a third group gathered at [[KLCC Park|Kuala Lumpur City Centre (KLCC) Park]] beneath the [[Petronas Twin Towers]].{{cite news |title=Malaysian Police Fire Tear Gas at Kuala Lumpur Protesters |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-07-09/malaysian-police-fire-tear-gas-at-kuala-lumpur-protesters.html |publisher=Bloomberg |date=9 July 2011 |author1=Manirajan Ramasamy |last2=Gan |first2=Gan |accessdate=9 July 2011}} Thousands eventually gathered at KLCC but were dispersed by police using tear gas and chemically-laced water.{{cite news |title=Clashes, chaos in KL as police fire on crowds |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/09/thousands-march-numbers-swell-by-the-minute/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} By 18:40 in the evening, police had confirmed 1,667 arrests, including 167 females and minors.{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/07/08/bloomberg1376-LO2LKK0UQVI901-093V3E0G483HR0O083LMTPRJNH.DTL |title=Malaysian Police Fire Tear Gas, Arrest 1,667 in Street Protests |date=9 July 2011 |work=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=9 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713135418/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fg%2Fa%2F2011%2F07%2F08%2Fbloomberg1376-LO2LKK0UQVI901-093V3E0G483HR0O083LMTPRJNH.DTL |archivedate=13 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Most of the arrested protestors, including Ambiga, were freed by the end of the day.{{cite news |title=Ambiga and Hadi freed, claim victory for democracy |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169419 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=9 July 2011 |last1=Aw |first1=Nigel |last2=Sipalan |first2=Joseph |accessdate=10 July 2011}} One death was reported. Protestor Baharuddin Ahmad accidentally inhaled tear gas fired by police. He was later arrested, but when he started to black out police didn't do anything and just stood there and watched. He was restrained by handcuffs which made the matters worse and he wasn't released because police lost the keys. After 15 minutes, an ambulance was called but never arrived. Finally, a volunteer took Baharuddin to a nearby hospital but it was already too late.{{cite news |title=Protest claims one life |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/09/protest-claims-one-life/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=9 July 2011 |author=Tarani Palani |accessdate=9 July 2011}} Police said he died of heart complications.{{cite news |title=Bersih 2.0 protester died of heart problem |url=http://www.nst.com.my/nst/articles/Bersih2_0protesterdiedofheartproblem/Article/ |work=[[New Straits Times]] |date=10 July 2011 |accessdate=10 July 2011}}http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169469http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169480{{Cite web |url=http://en.harakahdaily.net/index.php/headline/3109-questions-surround-baharudins-death-despite-police-denial.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=11 July 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713220556/http://en.harakahdaily.net/index.php/headline/3109-questions-surround-baharudins-death-despite-police-denial.html |archive-date=13 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ===International protests=== Bersih rallies also commenced in Melbourne, Sydney, Perth, Adelaide, Brisbane and Canberra, Australia, attracting around 750 people, 300 people, 200 people, 150 people, 50 people and 30 people respectively. Rallies were also reported in Auckland, Wellington and Christchurch, New Zealand,{{cite news|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169398|title=Global Bersih rallies kick off in Melbourne|date=9 July 2011|work=[[Malaysiakini]]|accessdate=9 July 2011}}http://www.greenleft.org.au/node/48113 as well as in London, England.{{cite news|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/10/nation/9074540&sec=nation|title=Pro-Bersih rallies in Melbourne, London|date=10 July 2011|work=[[The Star (Malaysia)]]|accessdate=10 July 2011}} A gathering of about 120 people was reported at the [[Speakers' Corner, Singapore|Speaker's Corner]] at [[Hong Lim Park]], Singapore.http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_689148.html Further rallies were reported in central Hong Kong,http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169410 Taiwan,http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2011/07/10/2003507872 Japan, South Korea, Switzerland, Sweden, France, England, Scotland, Ireland, Canada and the United States.{{cite web|last=Teoh, Sukumaran|first=El Sen, Tashny|title=Bersih Walk Around the World|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/11/bersih-walks-around-the-world/|publisher=Free Malaysia Today|accessdate=11 July 2011}} ==Aftermath== National laureate [[A. Samad Said]] called the rally a "great success", lauding the multiracial unity among the protestors.{{cite news |title=Bersih says 50,000 protested, declares rally ‘great success’ |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-says-50000-protested-declares-rally-great-success/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} Ambiga, speaking after being released, congratulated those who attended the rally, saying "we were not intimidated." The Bersih leadership commended protestors for behaving peacefully and condemned the police for reacting harshly to the demonstration.{{cite news |title=This is just the beginning, says polls coalition |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169403 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} They said the gathering was "not the end, it is but one more step in the long walk for clean and fair elections in Malaysia." Leader of the Opposition [[Anwar Ibrahim]] said the rally was a "success" despite "police brutality."{{cite news |title=Anwar: I suffered a bruise and a cut leg |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169433 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=9 July 2011 |author=AFP |authorlink=Agence France Presse |accessdate=10 July 2011}} DAP secretary-general [[Lim Guan Eng]] said the "police abuse" was "a big blow to the image of Malaysia."{{cite news |title=Guan Eng: Police abuse at rally bad image for M'sia |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169454 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=10 July 2011 |last=Loone |first=Susan |accessdate=10 July 2011}} Prime Minister [[Najib Razak]] downplayed the rally, insisting it only represented a minority of the population.{{cite news |title=Najib: Let illegal rally be a lesson to the people |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/10/nation/9074694&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=10 July 2011 |accessdate=10 July 2011}} He also said the anti-government sentiment among the protestors confirmed the government's fears that Bersih's agenda had been hijacked by the opposition. Home Minister [[Hishamuddin Hussein]] praised the police for keeping the rally under control and said the rally revealed itself to be an opposition plot.{{cite news |title=Bersih rally lost direction, says Hishammuddin |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-rally-lost-direction-says-hishammuddin/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=9 July 2011}} The United States expressed concern over the crackdown. [[United States Department of State|State Department]] spokesman Mark Toner said "We stand for... the right for people to freely express their democratic aspirations and express their views freely."{{cite news |title=US concern at Malaysia crackdown on protests |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-14149828 |work=BBC News |date=14 July 2011 |accessdate=14 July 2011}} Amnesty International released a statement saying: "This brutal crackdown on peaceful protesters is undermining Malaysia’s claim to be a moderate democracy. Mr. Najib’s government has chosen the path of repression, not reform." Lawyers for Liberty released a statement saying that the police deliberately shot gas canisters against the protestors.http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169623 ===Reform proposals=== On 15 August 2011, Najib announced that a parliamentary select committee will be formed to examine the electoral system. He said the committee will consist of members of parliament from both the government and opposition coalition who will discuss electoral reform issues "so that a mutual agreement can be reached."{{cite news |title=In nod to Bersih, PM announces vote system relook |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/pm-announces-bi-partisan-panel-to-study-vote-system/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=15 August 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=15 August 2011}} In his [[Malaysia Day]] 2011 address in September, Najib announced the government's intentions to repeal the [[Internal Security Act (Malaysia)|Internal Security Act]], [[Emergency Ordinance]], remove the annual renewal of press and publication permits, and review Section 27 of the [[Police (Malaysia) Act 1967|Police Act]].{{cite web |title=PM announces repeal of ISA, three Emergency proclamations |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/9/15/nation/20110915205714&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120101122631/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F9%2F15%2Fnation%2F20110915205714&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=1 January 2012 |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=15 September 2011 |accessdate=15 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }} In November 2011, the government tabled the [[Peaceful Assembly Act]] to replace Section 27 of the Police Act.{{cite news |title=Gathering in peace |url=http://www.nst.com.my/opinion/editorial/gathering-in-peace-1.9695 |work=[[New Straits Times]] |date=23 November 2011 |accessdate=23 November 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111123165426/http://www.nst.com.my/opinion/editorial/gathering-in-peace-1.9695 |archive-date=23 November 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ==Coverage and analysis== ===Pre-rally=== The lead-up to the rally has received polarising coverage in Malaysia's print and internet news media. Malaysia's print media are subject to the [[Printing Presses and Publications Act]], which stipulates they can only publish with a license granted by the [[Ministry of Home Affairs (Malaysia)|Ministry of Home Affairs]].{{cite journal|title=Malaysia |url=http://pcmlp.socleg.ox.ac.uk/archive/transition/issue07/malaysia.htm |work=Communications Law in Transition Newsletter |publisher=Oxford University, [[Yeshiva University]] |volume=1 |number=7 |date=4 September 2000 |accessdate=21 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724150414/http://pcmlp.socleg.ox.ac.uk/archive/transition/issue07/malaysia.htm |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df=dmy }} A news website has alleged that the [[Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission]] instructed radio and television stations to omit coverage of police violence and focus on the damage done by rally participants.{{cite news |title=Govt to media: Black out police violence during rally |url=http://en.harakah.net.my/index.php/berita-utama/3046-govt-to-media-black-out-police-violence-during-rally.html |work=Harakah Daily |date=1 July 2011 |accessdate=3 July 2011}} State news agency [[Bernama]] quoted several political analysts saying that the rally will tarnish Malaysia's image abroad and is a distraction from [[Anwar Ibrahim]]'s ongoing [[Anwar Ibrahim sodomy trials|sodomy trials]]. It claimed the 1998 demonstrations against Anwar's arrest and the 2007 Bersih rally caused "inconvenience to the public and damage to public property, attracting bad publicity from the international media." One analyst said elections are "already fair as fair can be."{{cite news |title=Illegal assembly will tarnish Malaysia’s good image: Analysts |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/23/nation/20110623171618&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=23 June 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=24 June 2011}} Bernama also reported analysts saying that Ambiga has a history of provoking Muslims and working against interests of the Malay community.{{cite news |title=Malays should know who Ambiga is, say analysts |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/26/malays-should-know-who-ambiga-is-say-analysts/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=26 June 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=26 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110627032803/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/26/malays-should-know-who-ambiga-is-say-analysts/ |archive-date=27 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ====Print media==== ''[[Utusan Malaysia]]'', a newspaper owned by the [[United Malays National Organisation]] (UMNO), a governing party, criticised the rally as "dirty" on a 12 June editorial. In particular, it made reference to Anwar's sodomy trial and sex video allegations, calling him a hypocrite and urging Malaysians to protest against the opposition leader instead. It also warned against disunity among [[Malay people|Malays]], and claimed that the DAP, backed strongly by Chinese constituents, would benefit most from the rally.{{cite news |title=Utusan says Bersih dirty, calls for boycott |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/utusan-says-bersih-dirty-calls-for-boycott/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=12 June 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=13 June 2011}} ''Utusan'' reported that 70 percent of the 1000 who attended the Bersih 2.0 pre-launch on 19 June were non-Malay.{{cite news |title=70 peratus bukan Melayu hadir |url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2011&dt=0621&pub=Utusan_Malaysia&sec=Dalam_Negeri&pg=dn_06.htm |work=[[Utusan Malaysia]] |date=20 June 2011 |accessdate=20 June 2011}} The newspaper has also portrayed the rally as anti-Islam.{{cite news |title=Bukan budaya Islam |url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2011&dt=0701&pub=Utusan_Malaysia&sec=Dalam_Negeri&pg=dn_09.htm |work=[[Utusan Malaysia]] |language=Malay |date=30 June 2011 |accessdate=30 June 2011}} They quoted pro-UMNO political analysts attacking Ambiga for "angering Muslims and Malays,"{{cite news |title=Utusan demonises Ambiga ahead of Bersih rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/utusan-demonises-ambiga-ahead-of-bersih-rally/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=26 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=27 June 2011}} as well as reported that foreign Christian organisations are funding the rally.{{cite news |title=Utusan says foreign Christian funds behind Bersih |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/utusan-says-foreign-christian-funds-behind-bersih/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=27 June 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=27 June 2011}} Tay Tian Yan wrote in the ''[[Sin Chew Daily]]'', the highest circulated daily in Malaysia, that the rally is a repeat scenario of the 2007 protest, where the opposition cashed in on public discontent over rising prices and staged the rally to generate momentum ahead of the general election. He also noted that the counter-rally by UMNO Youth is a ploy by BN to mitigate the Bersih rally's momentum, as opposed to suppressing the rally outright, which he said would swing public opinion against BN.{{cite news |title=Massive mobilisation |url=http://www.mysinchew.com/node/59071 |work=[[Sin Chew Daily]] |date=20 June 2011 |last=Tay |first=Tuan Yan |accessdate=21 June 2011}} Lim Sue Goan noted the involvement of Pakatan Rakyat and UMNO in opposite rallies, and said the event has grown from becoming a mere march to demand free elections to a political showdown between the government and opposition.{{cite news |title=Political struggle |url=http://www.mysinchew.com/node/59584 |work=[[Sin Chew Daily]] |date=28 June 2011 |last=Lim |first=Sue Goan |accessdate=29 June 2011}} In a 22 June editorial, [[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'']], owned by the [[Malaysian Chinese Association]] (MCA), also a governing party, said opposition parties are colluding with the rally's organisers to discredit the authorities in an attempt to gain support ahead of the elections. It accused Bersih of "[creating] cynical distrust in the authorities to give [themselves] and their political ringleaders a psychological advantage."{{cite news |title=Bersih 2.0 rally is still politics all the same |url=http://thestar.com.my/columnists/story.asp?col=thestarsays&file=/2011/6/22/columnists/thestarsays/8949840&sec=The%20Star%20Says |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=22 June 2011 |accessdate=27 June 2011}} Johan Jaaffar, chairman of Media Prima (owned by UMNO), the parent company of the ''[[New Straits Times]]'', wrote in the paper: "The government of the day is not perfect. So, too, the system... we don't solve problems on the streets. That's not us, nor our way."{{cite news |title=We don't solve problems on the streets |url=http://www.nst.com.my/nst/articles/19joja/Article/#ixzz1RZbx0HPC |work=[[New Straits Times]] |date=7 July 2011 |author=Johan Jaaffar |accessdate=9 July 2011}} M Faqih, writing in the PAS organ ''Harakah Daily'', compared the planned rally to the September 1998 protests in Kuala Lumpur against then-deputy prime minister [[Anwar Ibrahim]]'s sacking and detention on sodomy and corruption charges, which he described as peaceful unlike the [[Tunisian revolution|revolutions in Tunisia]] and [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egypt]]. He called on the opposition to seize the initiative with public discontent over government policies and use the rally as a stepping stone to victory in next general election.{{cite news |title=9 Julai penentu akhir tarikh PRU 13 |url=http://bm.harakahdaily.net/index.php/articles/analysis-a-opinion/3879-9-julai-penentu-akhir-tarikh-pru-13- |work=Harakah Daily |author=M Faqih |accessdate=21 June 2011}} ====Internet news==== Josh Hong of ''[[Malaysiakini]]'' questioned the law requiring protest organisers to obtain permits, saying the freedom of speech and right to assembly are guaranteed by the Constitution. He also criticised the government's record of cracking down civil rights campaigners and political activists and the mainstream media's demonisation of the Bersih rally.{{cite news |title=Najib is losing the plot – again |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/columns/169311 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=8 July 2011 |last=Hong |first=Josh |accessdate=8 July 2011}} Fellow columnists Mariam Mokhtar and Dean Johns criticised the government's crackdown on Bersih.{{cite news |title=The follies of Umno and the EC |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/columns/168837 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=4 July 2011 |author=Mariam Mokhtar |accessdate=8 July 2011}}{{cite news |title='Let them eat dirt' |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/columns/169047 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=5 July 2011 |last=Johns |first=Dean |accessdate=8 July 2011}} News website ''[[The Malaysian Insider]]'' called the government's tough stand against the Bersih rally "double standards," deriding the government's non-action against Ibrahim Ali, who had earlier called for [[jihad]] against Christians. It also blamed the police for the chaos that occurred during the 2007 rally and dismissed the government's concern for national security and threat to tourism as self-caused.{{cite news |title=Putrajaya’s double standards – The Malaysian Insider |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/sideviews/article/putrajayas-double-standards-the-malaysian-insider/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=13 June 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2011 }} The website reported analysts saying the rally will help PAS cement the growing support the party has gained among the Malay community.{{cite news |title=For PAS, Bersih rally catalyst to lead Malay vote |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/for-pas-bersih-rally-catalyst-to-lead-malay-vote/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=27 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=27 June 2011}} ''Free Malaysia Today'', another news website, argued in favour of the rally, saying that concerns that it will serve as a "spring offensive" to overthrow the government are exaggerated. It lamented what it perceived as Malaysia's flawed democracy, saying "[there] are two ways to punish political perverts who have raped democracy: vote them out or take to the streets." It also criticised the government for threatening to clamp down on protestors, saying that the ruling coalition is using public order as an excuse to preserve its stay in power.{{cite news |title=Don’t walk away from democracy |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/21/dont-walk-away-from-democracy/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=21 June 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2011}} In another editorial the day before the rally, FMT was highly critical of the government, asking the people to "decide the course of history" and defy a "harsh and repressive" state.{{cite news |title=People, the choice is yours |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/08/people-the-choice-is-yours/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ====International==== In an op-ed for ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', former US ambassador to Malaysia John R. Malott said Najib's UMNO is "running scared" of losing power and is waging a campaign of intimidation against Bersih. He called the protest "a brave step" towards the country's transition to full democracy.{{cite news |title=Running Scared in Malaysia |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303544604576431443001815406?mod=googlenews_wsj |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=8 July 2011 |last=Malott |first=John R. |accessdate=8 July 2011}} Professor Clive Kessler of the University of New South Wales in an interview with ABC Radio stated that the Agong's intervention was a rebuke to Umno and the government and an acknowledgement of Bersih’s legitimacy.{{Cite web |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/06/a-royal-rebuke-for-umno-says-aussie-don/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=12 July 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710134614/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/06/a-royal-rebuke-for-umno-says-aussie-don/ |archive-date=10 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ===Reactions to the rally=== Newspapers owned by Barisan Nasional parties were highly critical of the rally, accusing Bersih of disturbing the peace.{{cite news |title=Print media attacks Bersih, praises cops |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/print-media-attacks-bersih-praises-cops/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=10 July 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=10 July 2011}} ''[[Utusan Malaysia]]'' called the police operation to foil the illegal rally a success.{{cite news |title=Polis berjaya kekang Bersih |url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2011&dt=0710&pub=Utusan_Malaysia&sec=Muka_Hadapan&pg=mh_01.htm |work=[[Utusan Malaysia]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=10 July 2011 |language=Malay}} [[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'']] remarked in an editorial the following day: "If every complaint made one or the other party take to the streets, bringing a city to a standstill, people would not be getting much work done." It said Bersih achieved the publicity it sought, and that everyone should move on.{{cite news |title=The game is over, time for everybody to move on |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/10/nation/9074695&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=10 July 2011 |accessdate=10 July 2011}} The ''[[New Straits Times]]'' said there was "no winner in this madness" as many were hurt, and "Bersih's intentions were hijacked by the opposition coalition."{{cite news |title=No winner in this madness |url=http://www.nst.com.my/nst/articles/2bek/Article/#ixzz1Rfkmctle |work=[[New Straits Times]] |date=10 July 2011 |accessdate=10 July 2011}} NST's 10 July front page featured a photo of a protestor throwing an object with the headline "Peaceful?" ''[[The Malaysian Insider]]''{{'}}s Debra Chong said Najib's administration "took a massive punch to its gut," as accounts of police personnel using tear gas and water cannons against unarmed civilians were reported by international media. She said the rally showed the willingness of the middle class and civil society to stand up to the government.{{cite news |title=Today, Malaysians revisit Bersih 2007 |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/today-malaysians-revisit-bersih-2007/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |last=Chong |first=Debra |accessdate=9 July 2011}} TMI's Sheridan Mahavera said the rally was a display of racial unity.{{cite news |title=In Bersih, an elusive Malaysian unity appears |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/in-bersih-an-elusive-malaysian-unity-appears/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=10 July 2011 |author=Sheridan Mahavera |accessdate=10 July 2011}} Jeswan Kaur of ''Free Malaysia Today'' said Najib and the police were to blame for the chaotic scenes.{{cite news |title=Bersih rally revealed lots of truth |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/10/bersih-rally-revealed-lots-of-truth/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=10 July 2011 |author=Jeswan Kaur |accessdate=10 July 2011}} Ibrahim Suffian, head of the Merdeka Center, an independent think tank, said the actions of Bersih and the government polarised Malaysians of opposite political opinions. "For Pakatan Rakyat supporters, it has just increased their scepticism of the [BN-ruled] government. For those who are pro-government, it has hardened their belief that the PR is out to cause trouble." One analyst accused Barisan Nasional of abusing public institutions to protect its power,{{cite news |title=BN slammed for ‘feudal politics’ |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/10/bn-slammed-for-%E2%80%98feudal-politics%E2%80%99/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=10 July 2011 |author=Athi Shankar |accessdate=10 July 2011}} while another added that "the police lost more credibility than the protesters." International reaction was unanimously critical of the government. The Singapore [[The Straits Times|''Straits Times'']] added that Malaysian society has been polarised by the country’s divisive politics as clearly demonstrated when thousands braved a security lockdown of Kuala Lumpur.{{Cite web |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/singapore-daily-says-najib-umno-badly-bruised-by-bersih-crackdown/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=12 July 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713143524/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/singapore-daily-says-najib-umno-badly-bruised-by-bersih-crackdown/ |archive-date=13 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} In an editorial, the [[The Jakarta Post|''Jakarta Post'']] described Malaysia as a "rich but not free" country, with its leaders still "laboring under an old paradigm" and refusing to allow its people to exercise their rights to free speech by invoking racial tension.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/07/11/editorial-malaysia-rich-not-free.html|title=Malaysia: Rich, but not free|date=11 July 2011|accessdate=13 July 2011}} [[Al Jazeera English]]'s [[Teymoor Nabili]] said the government acted out of fear of an Egypt-style revolution.{{cite news |title=Malaysia's fear of Egypt |url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/asia/2011/07/08/malaysias-fear-egypt |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=9 July 2011 |last=Nabili |first=Teymoor |accessdate=9 July 2011}} [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] columnist William Pesek calls the rally a part of the "rising call for political change in Asia" that play a decisive role in foreign investment to Asian countries.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-07-12/investing-101-means-looking-out-the-windows-more-william-pesek.html|last=Pesek|first=William|title=Investing 101 Means Looking Out the Windows More|date=13 July 2011|accessdate=14 July 2011|work=Bloomberg}} The Asian Sentinel stated that although Najib Tun Razak appears to have won the battle by closing down Kuala Lumpur on Saturday and arresting 1,667 mostly peaceful marchers and would-be marchers, the consensus seems to be that Malaysia has suffered a blow to its international reputation as a moderate, democratic country.http://www.asiasentinel.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3307&Itemid=251 ''[[The Guardian]]''{{'}}s Simon Tisdall slammed Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's harsh treatment towards the peaceful rally participants, noting that the British Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] should tell Najib that "strong-arm tactics against protesters are unacceptable" and that "Malaysia's leaders should wake up and smell the coffee".[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/jul/13/malaysia-najib-cameron-protesters Malaysia's Najib must abandon the Mubarak model] ===Censorship=== ''[[The Economist]]''{{'}}s coverage of the rally was partially censored by the government. Four lines in the article titled "Taken to the cleaners – an overzealous government response to an opposition rally" was inked out.{{cite news |title=Home Ministry censors Bersih article in The Economist |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/home-ministry-censors-bersih-article-in-the-economist/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=19 July 2011 |first=Clara |last=Chooi |accessdate=15 August 2011}} Najib later admitted that censoring parts of the article was a mistake which generated negative publicity.{{cite news |title=Najib: Censorship no longer ‘effective’, needs review |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/najib-censorship-no-longer-effective-needs-review/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=15 August 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=15 August 2011}} ==Criticism== ===Election Commission=== The [[Election Commission of Malaysia]] (EC) has dismissed Bersih's claims, saying that it has already met the organisation's demands. EC chairman Abdul Aziz Mohd Yusof, who met with Bersih officials in December 2010, slammed Bersih chairman Ambiga's knowledge of voter registration as "shallow."{{cite news |title=SPR jawab tuntutan 'Bersih' |url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2011&dt=0614&pub=Utusan_Malaysia&sec=Rencana&pg=re_01.htm |work=[[Utusan Malaysia]] |author=Zulkifli Jalil |language=Malay |accessdate=13 June 2011}} Abdul Aziz also claimed that Bersih had a political agenda, saying that the opposition parties were propping up the organisation. He claimed the opposition were using the EC as a scapegoat for political gain.{{cite news |title=EC tells Bersih: Don’t make EC a scapegoat |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/20/nation/20110620190723&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=20 June 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=20 June 2011}} ====Response to demands==== * Responding to Bersih's demand that voter registration be automatic once a citizen reaches voting age, Abdul Aziz said such a proposal would contravene [[:s:Constitution of Malaysia#Article 119|Article 119 (4)]] of the Constitution, which he claims clearly states that registration as a voter can only be done through application by the voter him/herself. EC deputy chairman Wan Ahmad Wan Omar added that unregistered voters are "indifferent," and will not bother to vote anyway.{{cite news |title=EC shoots down Bersih’s demands ahead of rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ec-shoots-down-bersihs-demands-ahead-of-rally/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=30 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=30 June 2011}} * Abdul Aziz also defended against allegations that the EC is lackadaisical in tackling [[Ghost voter|phantom voting]]. He said that the EC cannot strike names of dead voters off the electoral roll unless the family of a dead voter requests it and produces the dead voter's death certificate. He also blamed allegations of voting in multiple constituencies on voters who refuse to change the addresses on their identification cards when they move homes. * Wan Ahmad said the use of [[indelible ink]] is "regressive" and only practised in less developed countries. He also raised the possibility of voters not wanting their fingers inked and voters who somehow inked their fingers before voting. Abdul Aziz said the EC was considering a [[biometric]] [[fingerprint]]ing system instead. * Wan Ahmad said a 21-day campaign period is "unnecessary" as Malaysia has a relatively small land area and population. ===Government=== The rally has been roundly criticised by government politicians, who claim that the opposition are using the rally, purportedly a non-partisan protest, to advance its own political agenda.{{cite news |title=Muhyiddin says opposition using Bersih rally to topple BN |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/muhyiddin-says-opposition-using-bersih-rally-to-topple-bn/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=18 June 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Bersih Assembly Only to Serve the Political Agenda of Opposition Parties |url=http://my.news.yahoo.com/bersih-assembly-only-serve-political-agenda-opposition-parties-063824776.html |work=[[Yahoo! News]] |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |date=17 June 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Bersih being used by the opposition for their agenda, says Chua |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/22/nation/8949063&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=22 June 2011 |last=Loh |first=Ivan |accessdate=22 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Muhyiddin insists Bersih political, threat to security |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/muhyiddin-insists-bersih-political-threat-to-security/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=25 June 2011 |last=Chi |first=Melissa |accessdate=25 June 2011}} Some ministers also accused the rally organisers of attempting a coup d'état.{{cite news |title=Rais: ‘Bersih in a plot to overthrow govt’ |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/27/rais-bersih-in-a-plot-to-overthrow-govt/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=27 June 2011 |last=Lee |first=Patrick |accessdate=27 June 2011}} Prime minister Najib said claims that elections are unfair "did not make sense," adding that the opposition are using instability to their political advantage. He challenged them to take on the government in the polls instead. The Home Minister, Hishamuddin, responding to early reports announcing the rally, criticised public demonstrations in particular. He slammed Bersih for trying to "instill hatred" and "show the world that our country is chaotic." Deputy Prime Minister [[Muhyiddin Yassin]] said the planned rally is "undemocratic" and claimed that it is supported only by a small segment of the population.{{cite news |title=Bersih rally undemocratic, says Muhyiddin |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-rally-undemocratic-says-muhyiddin/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=16 June 2011 |author=Asrul Hadi Abdullah Sani |accessdate=16 June 2011}} He also warned of foreign powers taking advantage of instability in Malaysia.{{cite news |title=DPM warns of outside interference |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/02/dpm-warns-of-outside-interference/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=2 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ===UMNO=== UMNO's information chief [[Ahmad Maslan]] said that the event might risk damaging the economy and national security.{{cite news |title=Umno against Bersih 2.0, says info chief |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/umno-against-bersih-2.0-says-info-chief/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=14 June 2011 |accessdate=14 June 2011}} UMNO Youth leader Khairy Jamaluddin said Anwar's attempts to exert influence over the rally on 19 June was proof that Bersih was "compromised" by the opposition. UMNO Youth executive council member Tengku Azman Tengku Zainol Abidin said public rallies should not be held on the streets and that the 2007 Bersih rally "achieved nothing." Anwar's former political secretary [[Dewan Negara|Senator]] Ezam Mohd Noor called Anwar a hypocrite, saying that Anwar's own PKR party election in 2010 was rife with allegations of manipulation.{{cite news |title=Khairy: ‘Stock up’ statement a threat to Chinese community |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/21/nation/8941713&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=21 June 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2011}} ===Perkasa=== Perkasa has criticised the rally for threatening to spread chaos, claiming that the opposition will use the rally to trigger an uprising similar to [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egypt]] and [[2011 Libyan civil war|Libya]]. Perkasa president [[Ibrahim Ali (Malaysia)|Ibrahim Ali]] also threw his support behind the EC, arguing that they had already answered demands for free and fair elections. [[Ibrahim Ali (Malaysia)|Ibrahim Ali]] also warned Chinese community should avoid joining this rally and stay away from it by keeping food at home. ===Independents=== "Independent" Member of Parliament [[Zulkifli Nordin]] questioned the need for the rally, claiming that democracy was already "alive," citing the result of the previous election as an example. Fellow independent MP [[Wee Choo Keong]] hinted that Bersih's cause is "politically motivated," and advised Ambiga to join a political party instead of "hiding behind a non-governmental organisation."{{cite news |title=Go join a political party, Wee tells Ambiga |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/15/nation/8901511&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=15 June 2011 |accessdate=15 June 2011}} ===Business=== Sections of the business community initially condemned the proposed street rally, arguing that business operators would have suffered losses on 9 July, a Saturday.{{cite news |title=Group: Bersih demo will be bad for business |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/25/nation/8975159&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=25 June 2011 |accessdate=30 June 2011}} Among the groups opposed to the rally were the KL and Selangor Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry,{{cite news |title=Business community ‘no’ to planned Bersih rally |url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2011/06/23/business-community-%E2%80%98no%E2%80%99-to-planned-bersih-rally/ |work=Borneo Post |date=23 June 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=30 June 2011}} the Malaysian Associated Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry,{{cite news |title=Indian businesses strongly against street demos |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/30/nation/9000836&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=30 June 2011 |accessdate=30 June 2011}} and the Executive Taxi Owners' Association.{{cite news |title=Cabbies rally against Bersih march |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/30/nation/8999247&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=30 June 2011 |accessdate=30 June 2011}} UMNO encouraged business operators and taxi drivers to sue Bersih for any losses that may be caused by the rally.{{cite news |title=Golongan terjejas dinasihat saman Bersih |url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2011&dt=0615&pub=Utusan_Malaysia&sec=Muka_Hadapan&pg=mh_04.htm |work=[[Utusan Malaysia]] |language=Malay |date=14 June 2011 |accessdate=15 June 2011}} ==See also== * [[Elections in Malaysia]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://bersih.org/ Bersih 2.0] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110621011418/http://bersih.org/?page_id=115 Joint Communiqué] issued by Bersih * [http://www.pemudaumno.org.my/ UMNO Youth] * [https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL40BBE1FF3E2C547D YouTube.com channel of public's account on Bersih 2.0 Rally] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110717093109/http://www.politweet.org/site/july9rally_crowdmap.php Crowd estimation] {{Malaysian protests and rallies}} {{Anti-government protests in the 21st century}}
